thread.title: Heathrow expansion: How every North East MP voted on controversial third runway plans

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Heathrow expansion: How every North East MP voted on controversial third runway plans
text:
Laura Pidcock (Labour - North West Durham) Read More Heathrow third runway to go ahead at last, as MPs back expansion plans
A group of councils and campaigners against the plans are now preparing to take the Government to court to block the move.
A judicial review against the decision is being launched by four London local authorities affected by the expansion - Wandsworth, Richmond, Hillingdon and Hammersmith and Fulham - in partnership with Greenpeace and mayor Sadiq Khan.
An hour before MPs voted, environmental activists staged a lie-in just metres away from the Commons chamber.
Police locked-down the Central Lobby area after the 12 protesters, who described themselves as from a “pop-up” Vote No Heathrow campaign, sprawled across the floor while chanting.
The plans have been met by pockets of strong opposition within both Labour and the Conservatives.
Former Northern Ireland Secretary Theresa Villiers was one of eight Conservative MPs to rebel against the Government, as well as Greg Hands, who quit as a minister ahead of the vote so he could oppose the plans.
Boris Johnson, a long-time opponent of expansion, missed the vote as he was in Afghanistan. Read More
The Foreign Secretary, who could have been forced to quit the Government if he had voted against the Government, was mocked for failing to appear with MPs shouting “where’s Boris?”.
Labour is officially opposed to the move but allowed a free vote on the measure.
The plans will create 114,000 extra jobs in the area around the airport by 2030, with an extra 16 million long-haul seats by 2040, according to officials.
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said support for the new runway would set a “clear path to our future as a global nation in the post-Brexit world”.
Boris Johnson challenged to quit over Heathrow expansion controversy
He said: “This is a really important moment in the history of this House and the history of this country.” Read More
Carolyn Fairbairn, director-general of business lobby group the CBI, described the support for expansion as a “truly historic decision” which will “open the doors to a new era in the UK’s global trading relationships”.
Building a new runway will “lift prosperity across the country”, she said.
But some opponents of expansion said they were not reassured by Government promises that “up to” 15% of new flights enabled by a third runway would be reserved for regional airports.
Grahame Morris, Labour MP for Easington, said: “The Secretary of State said that one of the key selling points is connectivity with our regional airports, but that will be only up to 15% of the new capacity.
“He has already indicated there will be 100 extra flights a day from Scotland, and as that 15% of new capacity is for all the regional airports and the Crown dependencies, it does not sound like a very good deal to me.” Like us on Facebook
